result.markdown:
---
title: "Testes de Hipótese para dois Grupos"
format: html
editor: visual
execute: 
  error: false
  warning: false
---

Técnica estatística usada para tomar decisões ou inferências sobre uma população com base em uma amostra de dados. O objetivo do teste de hipótese é determinar se há evidências suficientes nos dados da amostra para rejeitar uma suposição específica sobre a população.Neste caso teremos dois grupos, sendo cada grupo uma amostra de uma população 

## Testes Paramétricos 

### Teste t 

Usado para comparar as médias de dois grupos. Ele determina se as diferenças entre as médias dos dois grupos são estatisticamente significativas

#### Teste t não pareado 

Quando os grupos são independentes.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(gsheet)

mg <- gsheet2tbl("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bq2N19DcZdtax2fQW9OHSGMR0X2__Z9T/edit#gid=983033137")
mg
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 20 × 3
   trat      rep  comp
   <chr>   <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Mg2         1   9  
 2 Mg2         2  12.5
 3 Mg2         3  10  
 4 Mg2         4   8  
 5 Mg2         5  13.2
 6 Mg2         6  11  
 7 Mg2         7  10.8
 8 Mg2         8   9.5
 9 Mg2         9  10.8
10 Mg2        10  10.4
11 control     1  13.7
12 control     2  15.9
13 control     3  15.7
14 control     4  14.2
15 control     5  15.9
16 control     6  16.5
17 control     7  18  
18 control     8  14.4
19 control     9  16.4
20 control    10  16  
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
library(ggplot2)
library(r4pde)
```
:::


##### Análise exploratória


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library (tidyverse)
theme_set(r4pde::theme_r4pde(font_size = 10))

mg|> 
  ggplot(aes(trat, comp))+ 
  geom_boxplot()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Testes-de-Hipótese-para-dois-Grupos_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


##### Realizando o teste t


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
##passar do formato longo para largo 
mg2 <- mg |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = trat, 
              values_from = comp)

## Realizando o teste t
t.test (mg2$Mg2, mg2$control)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Welch Two Sample t-test

data:  mg2$Mg2 and mg2$control
t = -8.1549, df = 17.354, p-value = 2.423e-07
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -6.490393 -3.825607
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
   10.520    15.678 
```


:::
:::

Houve diferença estatística, com p-valor<0,05, aceitamos assim a hipótese alternativa. 

##### Testar a normalidade e heterocedacidade dos dados 

Para o test t ter validade a normalidade dos resíduos tem maior importância


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
## normalidade dos resíduos
shapiro.test(mg2$control)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  mg2$control
W = 0.93886, p-value = 0.5404
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(mg2$control)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Testes-de-Hipótese-para-dois-Grupos_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
qqnorm(mg2$control)
qqline(mg2$control)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Testes-de-Hipótese-para-dois-Grupos_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-2.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(mg2$Mg2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  mg2$Mg2
W = 0.97269, p-value = 0.9146
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
qqnorm(mg2$Mg2)
qqline(mg2$Mg2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Testes-de-Hipótese-para-dois-Grupos_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-3.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(mg2$Mg2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Testes-de-Hipótese-para-dois-Grupos_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-4.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#teste de homogeneidade das variãncias 
var.test(mg2$control, mg2$Mg2)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	F test to compare two variances

data:  mg2$control and mg2$Mg2
F = 0.67654, num df = 9, denom df = 9, p-value = 0.5698
alternative hypothesis: true ratio of variances is not equal to 1
95 percent confidence interval:
 0.1680428 2.7237436
sample estimates:
ratio of variances 
         0.6765394 
```


:::
:::

##### Quando as variâncias são hogêneas 

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
t.test (mg2$Mg2, mg2$control, var.equal = TRUE)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Two Sample t-test

data:  mg2$Mg2 and mg2$control
t = -8.1549, df = 18, p-value = 1.863e-07
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -6.486839 -3.829161
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
   10.520    15.678 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
#OU
t.test (mg2$Mg2, mg2$control)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Welch Two Sample t-test

data:  mg2$Mg2 and mg2$control
t = -8.1549, df = 17.354, p-value = 2.423e-07
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -6.490393 -3.825607
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
   10.520    15.678 
```


:::
:::


Quando as variâncias não são homogêneas 

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
t.test (mg2$Mg2, mg2$control, var.equal = FALSE)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Welch Two Sample t-test

data:  mg2$Mg2 and mg2$control
t = -8.1549, df = 17.354, p-value = 2.423e-07
alternative hypothesis: true difference in means is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -6.490393 -3.825607
sample estimates:
mean of x mean of y 
   10.520    15.678 
```


:::
:::


##### Relatório do teste t 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(report)

teste_t_1 <- t.test (mg2$Mg2, mg2$control)

report(teste_t_1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
Effect sizes were labelled following Cohen's (1988) recommendations.

The Welch Two Sample t-test testing the difference between mg2$Mg2 and
mg2$control (mean of x = 10.52, mean of y = 15.68) suggests that the effect is
negative, statistically significant, and large (difference = -5.16, 95% CI
[-6.49, -3.83], t(17.35) = -8.15, p < .001; Cohen's d = -3.65, 95% CI [-5.12,
-2.14])
```


:::
:::


#### Teste t pareado

Quando os grupos são dependentes 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
escala<- gsheet2tbl("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bq2N19DcZdtax2fQW9OHSGMR0X2__Z9T/edit#gid=1729131173")

# exploração de dados 
escala|> 
  ggplot(aes(assessment, acuracia))+ 
  geom_boxplot() #houve significativamente melhor acurária com auxílio 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Testes-de-Hipótese-para-dois-Grupos_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::

```{.r .cell-code}
escala2 <- escala |>
  select( assessment, rater, acuracia) |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = assessment, 
              values_from = acuracia)

## testando a normalidade e heterocedacidade
shapiro.test(escala2$Unaided)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  escala2$Unaided
W = 0.7748, p-value = 0.007155
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(escala2$Aided1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  escala2$Aided1
W = 0.92852, p-value = 0.4335
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
var.test(escala2$Unaided, escala2$Aided1)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	F test to compare two variances

data:  escala2$Unaided and escala2$Aided1
F = 20.978, num df = 9, denom df = 9, p-value = 0.000106
alternative hypothesis: true ratio of variances is not equal to 1
95 percent confidence interval:
  5.210754 84.459185
sample estimates:
ratio of variances 
          20.97847 
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
# podemos proceder com teste paramétrico mesmo as variâncias não sendo heterogêneas 
t.test (escala2$Unaided, escala2$Aided1, paired = TRUE, 
        var.equal = FALSE)# regeito a hipótese nula, há diferença entre os tratamentos (p-valor<0,05) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Paired t-test

data:  escala2$Unaided and escala2$Aided1
t = -4.4214, df = 9, p-value = 0.001668
alternative hypothesis: true mean difference is not equal to 0
95 percent confidence interval:
 -0.3552353 -0.1147647
sample estimates:
mean difference 
         -0.235 
```


:::
:::


## Teste não paramétrico

### Teste de wilcox


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
escala <- gsheet2tbl("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1bq2N19DcZdtax2fQW9OHSGMR0X2__Z9T/edit#gid=1729131173")
escala 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
# A tibble: 20 × 7
   assessment rater acuracia precisao vies_geral vies_sistematico vies_constante
   <chr>      <chr>    <dbl>    <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>          <dbl>
 1 Unaided    A         0.81     0.83       0.98             1.19           0.11
 2 Unaided    B         0.72     0.73       0.99             0.92          -0.11
 3 Unaided    C         0.4      0.71       0.78             1.16           0.73
 4 Unaided    D         0.82     0.82       1                0.95          -0.01
 5 Unaided    E         0.75     0.75       0.99             1.1            0.07
 6 Unaided    F         0.45     0.75       0.92             0.8            0.34
 7 Unaided    G         0.81     0.82       0.98             1.16           0.13
 8 Unaided    H         0.78     0.87       0.9              1.07          -0.47
 9 Unaided    I         0.78     0.79       0.99             1.14           0.09
10 Unaided    J         0.5      0.83       0.74             0.65          -0.72
11 Aided1     A         0.91     0.95       0.96             0.89          -0.28
12 Aided1     B         0.91     0.96       0.95             0.89          -0.3 
13 Aided1     C         0.91     0.96       0.95             1.28           0.21
14 Aided1     D         0.96     0.97       0.99             1.14           0.09
15 Aided1     E         0.96     0.96       1                1             -0.1 
16 Aided1     F         0.9      0.97       0.93             0.86          -0.36
17 Aided1     G         0.85     0.95       0.89             0.83          -0.45
18 Aided1     H         0.88     0.97       0.9              1.29           0.38
19 Aided1     I         0.95     0.96       0.99             1.14           0.07
20 Aided1     J         0.94     0.96       0.99             0.91          -0.13
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
escala2 <- escala |>
  select( assessment, rater, acuracia) |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = assessment, 
              values_from = acuracia)

## testando a normalidade e heterocedacidade
shapiro.test(escala2$Unaided)## dados não paramétricos
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  escala2$Unaided
W = 0.7748, p-value = 0.007155
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
shapiro.test(escala2$Aided1) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Shapiro-Wilk normality test

data:  escala2$Aided1
W = 0.92852, p-value = 0.4335
```


:::

```{.r .cell-code}
## Teste de Wilcox
wilcox.test(escala2$Aided1, escala2$Unaided, paired = TRUE) # regeito a hipótese nula, há diferença entre os tratamentos (p-valor<0,05)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```

	Wilcoxon signed rank test with continuity correction

data:  escala2$Aided1 and escala2$Unaided
V = 55, p-value = 0.005889
alternative hypothesis: true location shift is not equal to 0
```


:::
:::
